She Made Them Dance
nytimes_articles.abstract:
One seldom has cause, these days, to complain that a new biography of a woman makes insufficient use of the gender card, but Carol Easton's life of Agnes de Mille is one of those rare occasions. In the 1940's, de Mille was, by her own account, "the best-known choreographer in America -- not the best, but the best known." Dance is a woman's field, but as de Mille pointed out, it was ceded to women only because men didn't consider it important enough to reserve it for  themselves. Furthermore, the area in which she made her deepest mark was not concert dance, the women's preserve, but musical comedy a genre more dominated by men -- men who, furthermore, regarded dancing as employment for the backer's  girlfriends. De Mille's struggle to be taken seriously in that world is a classic women's tale. 

      She was born, in 1905, into an eminent family. Her grandfather was the famous economist Henry George; her father, a successful playwright and screenwriter; her uncle, Cecil B. De Mille. As she grew, she developed an excellent mind, a big nose and a rather trying personality -- combative, demanding, complaining. (In later years, several people, without consulting one  another, nicknamed her Agony de Mille.) She spent her teen-age years sitting out the cotillion and writing poems and stories that her father critiqued. He wanted her to be a playwright. He also, she believed, wished she had been a boy, and she undoubtedly wished the same.

Skiing Bolivia Is High Comedy
nytimes_articles.abstract:
CHACALTAYA is Bolivia's only ski resort and, at more than 17,000 feet in altitude, unquestionably the world's highest. Its only run would hardly intimidate the most shrinking of novices if it were, say, three miles lower. But even bunny runs have a way of becoming booby traps the closer they get to outer  space. In this rarefied atmosphere, skiing is no ordinary test of skill. 

     Chacaltaya is an oval glacier blanketing a velvet hill on the Cordillera Real, the eastern of the two Andean ranges in Bolivia. It is 15 miles north of La Paz and visible from the upper reaches of the city. But its geographical proximity belies a nerve-racking 90-minute drive along roads that could induce vertigo in a condor. By comparison, the Matterhorn is 2,500 feet lower, and no one bothered to build a ski run there.

NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: EAST NEW YORK/BUSHWICK;With Pool Drydocked, a Champion Team Struggles
nytimes_articles.abstract:
By the time Omar Santiago sat back on a tiled bench and talked about setbacks for the Bushwick High School swimming team, a teammate was cutting through the pool under an elegant mosaic at Fort Hamilton High School. 

     "Eddie Cruz used to drop time like nothing," Mr. Santiago said of the swimmer as his other teammates shouted during the swimming meet last week. "I feel sorry for him because he was capable of doing better -- much better. Not only him, all the seniors."

NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: GREENWICH VILLAGE;Wanted on Washington Street
nytimes_articles.abstract:
In most neighborhoods, children learn three basic rules of street-crossing: Look both ways before stepping off the curb. Red lights mean stop. Green lights  mean go. But it's more complicated on Washington Street, where traffic lights are few and far between. There are no lights on Washington between Bethune and Christopher Streets, a distance of six blocks. 

     Twenty years ago, when the far West Village was still overwhelmingly industrial, the dearth of lights was not a hot issue. But today, the area has evolved into a mixed-use and residential neighborhood with thousands more residents. The growing numbers of popular restaurants are drawing more people and cars to the neighborhood. And more drivers are using Washington Street instead of the often-jammed West Side Highway. Traffic is likely to increase when the highway, known formally as Route 9A, is reconstructed as an urban boulevard starting in the spring.

CLASSICAL MUSIC;Finding Maestros for Podium . . .
nytimes_articles.abstract:
THE MATING DANCE between an orchestra and a prospective music director can be as circumspect as an old-fashioned courtship or as frank as a modern romance. 

     When the St. Louis Symphony began its quest for a successor to Leonard Slatkin two years ago, Bruce Coppock, its executive director, spent months sounding out international artist managers to gauge the interest of particular maestros. "You could call it a cat-and-mouse game," Mr. Coppock said, "but it's  rooted in the need to protect the privacy and reputations of those involved."

The Threshold of Suffering
FILM VIEW;Down To the Sea On Film
nytimes_articles.abstract:
IN THE MOVIE "WHITE SQUALL," which stars Jeff Bridges as the captain of a prep school training ship, we encounter the sea in the most horrifying of her moods. The white squall of the title -- a rare and dreaded freak of nature -- is brilliantly recreated, a tantrum that we can barely conceive of, an act of wind and water that claims the ship, the captain's wife, another crew member and four students. The storm is so violent and sudden it is deemed a fantasy in the  courtroom scene that ends the film: a courtroom scene in which the captain is charged with failing to adequately command his boat. 

     Many sea sagas seem to end in courtrooms, and the reason is clear. Audiences  need a debriefing on dry land after the unimaginable isolation of that different race and government of sailors at sea. And the judges, however sea-wise, always  come to the same conclusion: the prosecutors were not out there. They had days to prepare their case. The mariner had seconds to find a way for himself and his crew to live, out there, as alone in space as Apollo 13, and with no Mission Control.

TENNIS;A New McEnroe Shines in Davis Cup
Americans Keep On Trucking, and Big Pickups Still Pull Their Weight
Not Just Another Country
nytimes_articles.abstract:
To assert that America is exceptional, as analysts have been doing since Tocqueville, is to dwell on paradox. In "American Exceptionalism: A Double-Edged Sword," Seymour Martin Lipset motes that while the United States is the most litigious society in the world -- spending four to eight times as much on lawsuits as Germany, England, Italy, France, the Netherlands or Japan -- it is simultaneously one of the most lawless, vexed by crime rates triple those of other industialized nations. Hence America's double-edged sword: on one side of  the blade, "a high sense of personal responsibility, independent initiative and  voluntarism"; on the other side, "self-serving behavior, atomism and a disregard for communal good." 

      Central to Mr. Lipset's American exceptionalism is the idea of a definable American Creed, "a set of dogmas about the nature of a good society," deriving mostly from the Revolution. These include liberty, egalitarianism (defined as equality of opportunity, not result), individualism, populism and laissez-faire. To buttress his argument, he uses copious survey data to demonstrate how different America is from other advanced countries. For example, in 1992 just 38 percent of Americans agreed that government should reduce the difference in income between rich and poor, compared with 65 percent of Britons, 66 percent of West Germans and 80 percent of Italians.

nytimes_articles.headline: Proving to Mr. Dithers That It's Time for a Raise
nytimes_articles.abstract:
CATHY HOOT used to subscribe to the Dagwood Bumstead theory of getting a raise: throw yourself at the boss's mercy. It didn't always work. 

     So in 1994, she decided to take a more long-term approach. She set up an informal meeting with her boss and they talked about what he expected of her and what it would take to increase her compensation. They prepared a set of goals and got together periodically to see how she was doing.

PLAYING IN THE NEIGHBORHOOD
Apartment Hunting on the Grand Canal
nytimes_articles.abstract:
PERHAPS because Venice is such a dreamlike city, I've always been fascinated  by the details that attach it to everyday life: the milk boat, the hidden supermarket, the fresh fish stands that disappear by noon. For years my husband  and I wanted to live in Venice, not just visit -- but the monthlong rentals listed in the brochures we had received from several American real estate brokers were beyond our price range. Luckily we had found several brokers in Venice on previous visits. Their faxed replies to our inquiries were charming, and spoke of slightly cheaper, more intriguing options: "The apartment is very nice, with furniture in Style. There is also a washdisher." 

     Though we would fantasize about the charms of these apartments (the dangerous benefit of having no brochure), we hesitated to commit money to a sight-unseen -- even a month is a long time to be stuck with a mistake. Most of the Venetian  brokers gave up after a letter or two, but one -- Chiara Canal, of Gestioni Finanziarie Immobiliari -- kept trying. So on a gray day last spring, when we spied a cheap air fare to Italy, we faxed Chiara one last time. If she had a place on the Grand Canal, we'd go for just a week to see what our choices for a  month's stay really were.

SOAPBOX;Governor, Meet My Mother
nytimes_articles.abstract:
GOVERNOR WHITMAN calls her proposal to overhaul New Jersey's welfare system "tough love at its best." I call it shortsighted, and I speak from experience. 

     I was 15 when my family went on welfare in Jersey City. My mother was in the  middle of her fifth pregnancy; our father had deserted us. The welfare check for our family of six in 1964 was $333 a month. The rent for our roach- and rat-infested cold-water flat was $125, not including utilities. A rope around the refrigerator kept it shut. We walked to school with empty stomachs and holes in our shoes, and we lunched on mayonnaise sandwiches. Returning home, we stepped over drunks who took refuge in our hallway. We lived in constant fear of fire and violence.

nytimes_articles.headline: New & Noteworthy Paperbacks
nytimes_articles.abstract: CONFRONTING AUTHORITY: Reflections of an Ardent Protester By Derrick Bell. Beacon, $12. The author, Harvard Law School's first full-time black professor, took an unpaid leave from the faculty in 1990, intending to return only after the school hired  a woman of color. This book is not only a chronicle of his protest, which ultimately led to his dismissal, but also a call to arms for battles of conscience. "I found Mr. Bell's conclusion convincing," Laura Kalman said here in 1994.

nytimes_articles.headline: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: MILL BASIN;Businesses Say A Zoning Curb Is Misguided
nytimes_articles.abstract:
Residents on one side of Strickland Avenue are close to curbing the growth of their neighbors across the street. But those neighbors -- businesses that abut the still water of Mill Basin -- say they are being penalized because of community opposition to megastores. 

     "There will never be residential houses built on this property," said Neil Capone, who owns property that he last used for a waste-transfer station. "There are people grandfathered in that will never leave and the few vacant parcels won't be turned residential. Who will want to live here?"

BOOKEND;My Life: A Proposal
nytimes_articles.abstract:
TODAY marks the beginning of the 10th year I've spent on my novel "Dripping." Still convinced it will encompass everything I've learned from Chekhov, those exquisite small epiphanies in which nothing happens and all is revealed. To think there are those who don't realize how hard it is to achieve this mixture of mysterious everyday realism and emotional reticence! Especially in a passage like this: 

     He was setting down the money for his drink and putting on his coat. She had  no reason to be happy, for he had just told her he didn't love her, and yet she  heard the music from the jukebox and saw the lights from the taxis on the avenue and she felt overjoyed. Thank God she had remembered to take her Paxil.

SAFE-SEX LIES
FROM THE DESK OF: RICHARD G. GELDARD;I'd Rather Use a Checkbook
nytimes_articles.abstract:
RECENTLY, I began and ended a brief affair with on-line banking. 

     It started with a warm phone call from Chemical Bank in October and an invitation to go on line to handle all my finances. I was promised new experiences and wondrous control over all my banking needs. Because Chemical was my bank and I felt ready for adventure, I broke my rule against responding to phone merchandising and said yes.

Turtle Eggs = Prison for 2
The Tree of Life Grows in Mexico
nytimes_articles.abstract:
AN hour west of Mexico City, in a seemingly unrelated world of clean air, cornfields and a country pace, artisans in the town of Metepec shape clay into an unusual and delightful form: trees. Most represent stories -- against a backdrop of clay trunks and branches, Adam and Eve face temptation by the serpent, Noah tends to his Ark, or more modern scenes unfold in a world of painstaking intricacy. 

     These arboles de la vida (trees of life) have been the town's signature for a half-century. Similar pieces are produced in a few other towns in Mexico, but nowhere else are they made as prolifically or, perhaps, as charmingly as in Metepec.

Ideas & Trends;Single Motherhood: Stereotypes vs. Statistics
nytimes_articles.abstract:
NOTHING evokes fears that traditional family values are declining more than the steeply rising number of children born out of wedlock. The discouragement of illegitimacy is a major goal of proposed welfare changes that are edging closer  to approval in Washington. 

     The compromise advanced by a bipartisan coalition of governors last week would empower states to deny benefits to children born to unwed women under the  age of 18.

nytimes_articles.headline: Delta Blues
nytimes_articles.abstract: MISSISSIPPI An American Journey. By Anthony Walton. Illustrated. 279 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $24.    TO understand the world, William Faulkner once said, you have to understand a place like Mississippi. Anthony Walton began working on this fine and brave book five years ago, when he was 30. In his incessant confrontations with racism in the North, he was having doubts about whether he wanted to be an American. He was too contentedly bourgeois, he confesses, to look toward Africa, and besides  did not know his tribe. The more he thought, the less he could deny it: "I was from somewhere. Mississippi was my heritage and background, and if I wanted to decipher the tangle of contradictions and illusions around me, I was first going to have to learn to decipher myself." He adds: "If I was going to have to live out the fate of being black and American, I felt I needed to know what that meant. And that meant Mississippi."

NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: DOWNTOWN BROOKLYN;Strip Club (and Battle) Go On
nytimes_articles.abstract:
Steam Heat, a striptease club on Flatbush Avenue, has withstood court rulings, community protests and well-connected opponents since it opened last April. Not once, in the face of its many losses, has one of its nude dancers had to halt a performance. 

     "We keep on winning the battles, but we don't win the war," Borough President Howard Golden, one of the club's ardent foes, said last week.  "Even sleazebags  have a right to appeal."

SOAPBOX;The Icicles That Loom Over Me
nytimes_articles.abstract:
THERE'S a big icicle hanging off my windowsill, and another, even bigger, hanging from the eaves just above me. Getting longer every day. I'm dying to give them a good whack and send them crashing four floors down into the courtyard of my little co-op building. I don't though. 

     I'm Miss Board President for Life here in the East 20's (small apartment, late 80's, bought high, no chance of selling). And a couple of years ago, I saw  the same big icicles hanging off my windowsill. They were right over our store tenant's back door. Hmmm, I thought. They could go crashing down and kill him and that would get us out of the sweetheart lease our sponsor stuck us with, the one that has our store tenant paying 300 bucks a month, more or less, till 2014.

wiki_events.headline: The Nepalese Civil War is initiated in the Kingdom of Nepal by the Communist Party of Nepal (Maoist-Centre).

pages.title: Nepalese Civil War
pages.abstract: The Nepalese Civil War (19962006) was a protracted and countrywide armed conflict in the then Kingdom of Nepal between the Kingdom's rulers and the Communist Party of Nepal (Maoist), with the latter making significant use of guerrilla warfare. It began on 13 February 1996, when the CPN(M) initiated an insurgency with the stated purpose of overthrowing the Nepali monarchy and establishing a people's republic. It ended with the signing of the Comprehensive Peace Accord on 21 November 2006.

pages.title: Kingdom of Nepal
pages.abstract: The Kingdom of Nepal was a Hindu kingdom in South Asia, formed in 1768 by the expansion of the Gorkha Kingdom, and disestablished and replaced by the Federal Democratic Republic of Nepal in 2008. The king of Nepal served as its head of state, and it was also known as the Gorkha Empire, or sometimes Asal Hindustan. The kingdom was founded by King Prithvi Narayan Shah, a Gorkha monarch of the Shah dynasty who claimed to be of Thakuri origin from chaubisi.

pages.title: Communist Party of Nepal (Maoist Centre)
pages.abstract: The Communist Party of Nepal (Maoist Centre) (Nepali:    ( ), romanized:Npla Kamyunisa Pr (M'vd Kndra)), abbreviated CPN (Maoist Centre) or CPN (MC), was a mainstream political party in Nepal. The party was dissolved automatically when the central committee announced a merger with eight other communist parties and groups to form the Nepali Communist Party. On the other hand, a group led by party joint general secretary Janardan Sharma including Ram Karki, Anjana Bisankhe and Sudan Kirati formed the Progressive Campaign, Nepal, alleging that the party leadership had left their ideological base for a "musical chair of leadership."
